titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Dial/Scofield Thayer Papers: Addition
titlestmt.author: by Diane J. Ducharme

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday January 23, 2019 at 05:14
profiledesc.descrules: translation missing: en.enumerations.resource_finding_aid_description_rules.beinecke manuscript unit archival processing manual

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence and personal papers of Scofield Thayer, including letters from Amy and Robert von Erdberg, Erik von Jurié, R. T. Nichol, and Florence Thayer. Personal papers include school compositions and other writings by Thayer; notes and memoranda; newspaper clippings; and photographs of the Gaston Lachaise portrait bust of Thayer.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased in 1987 with the assistance of the Beinecke Foundation and transferred to Beinecke Library in 1996.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Dial/Scofield Thayer Papers: Addition are the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Dial/Scofield Thayer Papers: Addition. Yale Collection of American Literature. Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p:
The materials are open for research.
Box 5: Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Dial/Scofield Thayer Papers YCAL MSS 34. Yale Collection of American Literature. Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

bioghist.head: SCOFIELD THAYER (1889-1982)
bioghist.p: Scofield Thayer was born in Worcester, Massachusetts in 1889 and educated at Milton Academy, Harvard College, and Oxford University. In 1919 Thayer and J. Sibley Watson purchased Dial magazine, which under their direction became perhaps the most important "little magazine" in the United States in the 1920s. Thayer withdrew from active participation in The Dial after a severe breakdown in 1926. He died in 1982.
For a fuller biography of Scofield Thayer, and a chronology for The Dial , see the register for YCAL MSS 34, Dial/Scofield Thayer Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
The Dial/Scofield Thayer Papers: Addition consists of four boxes of additional material to the Dial/Scofield Thayer Papers purchased in 1987. The Addition was transferred to the Beinecke Library in 1996. The papers span the dates 1885-1928, but the bulk of the material concerns the period 1915-1927. The papers are organized in two series. Series I, Correspondence
, is arranged alphabetically by correspondent; Series II, Personal Papers , alphabetically by type of material.

Correspondence consists almost entirely of letters sent to Thayer between 1926 and 1928, when he was hospitalized repeatedly following a mental breakdown. The writers, including Amy and Robert von Erdberg, Erik von Jurié, R. T. Nichol, Eleanor Schermerhorn, Ellen Thayer, and Lizzie Whittemore, send their wishes for improved health and sometimes detail plans for visits to MacLean Hospital. After one such visit, Amy von Erdberg wrote Thayer of her distress at seeing him hospitalized and offered to support his wish to be released. There are also two earlier letters from Thayer to his mother, Florence Thayer, and three third-party letters, two of which are to Florence Thayer also.

Series II, Personal Papers
, includes bookplates, calling cards, newspaper clippings about America's entry into World War I, which Thayer opposed, and photographs. Folders 31-39 contain notes and memoranda kept by Thayer, often on small slips of paper, although some were apparently transcribed by a secretary at a later date. These cover a wide variety of subjects, including Thayer's family and friends, his marriage, his analyses by L. Pierce Clark and Sigmund Freud, aesthetic theory, and modern painting and literature.

Folders 23-25 contain correspondence and personal papers of Lucian Cary, including an income tax return for 1917 identifying him as a "journalist" and his wife, Augusta Cary, as executive secretary of the National Birth Control League. The return appears to be in Thayer's hand.

The section "School papers" includes versions of Thayer's Harvard Class Day essay on Dr. Faustus and several papers he read to literary societies at Oxford. "Writings" includes two poems, "Spleen anglais" and "Vienna," several essays, and a group of sketches and anecdotes about a figure named "Mercury" or "Mr. Mercury." At least some of the typescripts contained in the "Pending" file in "Writings of Others" may be by Thayer, who frequently employed pseudonyms when submitting work to The Dial.
Oversize material is located in Box 4 and consists of newspaper clippings and seven photographs of Gaston Lachaise's portrait bust of Thayer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I, Correspondence , is alphabetically arranged by name of correspondent. Correspondence of others has been placed in the subseries Third- Party Correspondence, located at the end of the series, and alphabetically arranged by author.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With photographs of the von Erdbergs and clippings

did.unittitle: Lane, F. E. To Hermann P. Riccius

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With copies of two articles by Scofield Thayer that appeared in the Milton Academy Orange and Blue

did.unittitle: Sheehan, Vesta Blake to Florence Thayer

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II, Personal Papers is arranged alphabetically by type of material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence between Lucian Cary and Henry Ford's office; a letter to "Dear Bertie" signed "D. C." dated 18 Aug 1918; a request to French military censors for permission to publish an article in Collier's Weekly from Doris Cart; Liberty War Loan card and lapel pin; Cary's income tax return for 1917; and two unidentified photographs

did.unittitle: World War I: Press conspiracy charges

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With notes and safety deposit box receipt dated 1928

did.unittitle: Thayer, Scofield: portrait bust by Gaston Lachaise
Greek 6: " Dr Faustus and Greek Tragedy," typescript
"A Valentine (Pale regent of a thousand fragile dreams)," holograph and typescript
"Aesthetics" (paper read before an Oxford club, perhaps the Heretics), holograph
"Compton Mackenzie" ("read before the Nineties Club of Oxford on June 11, 1915"), typescript
Notebook on [the Novum Organum of?] Sir Francis Bacon, holograph
Essay on Hugo Von Hofsmannthal, typescript
"My Neighbor, Mr. Mercury": various sketches, typescript
Review of the Harvard Monthly for January 1916, holograph
"Pending" file: includes typescripts attributed to "B. Beasley," "Israel Solon," and a manuscript, "A College President Denounces the Voluntary System"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Oversize material has been placed here in series order.

did.unittitle: Photographs: portrait bust of Thayer by Gaston Lachaise

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Box 5, Restricted Fragile Papers, contains fragile originals. The material is arranged in folder order and may only be seen with the permission of the appropriate curator.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Box 5: Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.
